articles.headline: Right on the $800,000 Question, They Lost Anyway
articles.snippet: Two contestants on Fox’s “Million Dollar Money Drop,” who lost $800,000 on an answer that turned out to be correct, aren’t sure they’ll accept an invitation to return.
articles.abstract: Two contestants on Fox’s “Million Dollar Money Drop,” who lost $800,000 on an answer that turned out to be correct, aren’t sure they’ll accept an invitation to return.
articles.lead_paragraph: Which product was sold in stores first: Post-it Notes or the Sony Walkman?

articles.headline: Early Bid for a Reactor Site Draws Opposition in Texas
articles.snippet: Citing problems with the chosen site, a Texas group objects to Exelon’s plan to build a reactor sometime in the future.
articles.abstract: Citing problems with the chosen site, a Texas group objects to Exelon’s plan to build a reactor sometime in the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Twenty years ago, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission rewrote its procedure for licensing reactors to cut the time it would take to build new ones. Now an important part of the system is getting its first test, as a Chicago-based nuclear utility clashes with a well-to-do group of Texas ranchers over preapproval of a site about 120 miles southwest of Houston.

articles.headline: Bavaria Booms, but Germans Feel Economic Malaise
articles.snippet: Germany’s good fortune, however conspicuous to other Europeans, is viewed internally as having come at the expense of workers.
articles.abstract: Germany’s good fortune, however conspicuous to other Europeans, is viewed internally as having come at the expense of workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: ERLANGEN-HÖCHSTADT, Germany  By nearly every measure this industrial region in Bavaria, home to exporting giants like Siemens Healthcare, Adidas and Puma, is at the center of Germany’s resilient economic success, driving the nation’s growth even as much of Europe struggles to stay solvent.

articles.headline: Doctor Says a Device He Invented Poses Risks
articles.snippet: Scott Augustine, who invented the Bair Hugger, which warms patients during operations, says the machine shouldn’t be used on those receiving implant devices like artificial heart valves.
articles.abstract: Scott Augustine, who invented the Bair Hugger, which warms patients during operations, says the machine shouldn’t be used on those receiving implant devices like artificial heart valves.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dr. Scott D. Augustine, the inventor of a widely used piece of surgical equipment, now has a better idea  he wants hospitals to stop using the device during certain operations, asserting that it poses a danger to patients.

articles.headline: Redistricting Looms Large in Congress
articles.snippet: With Republicans poised to build on their gains from the midterm elections, Democrats are trying to save their jobs.
articles.abstract: With Republicans poised to build on their gains from the midterm elections, Democrats are trying to save their jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The political jockeying over how to draw new Congressional districts began in earnest this week after new census data showed almost a dozen seats shifting to the South and West, leaving Republicans poised to build on their gains from November’s midterm elections and forcing several northern Democratic incumbents to begin plotting to save their jobs.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: A Mortgage Nightmare’s Happy Ending
articles.snippet: A substantial modification of their mortgage helped Amy and Robert Ahleman keep their home. But while their story is uplifting, it’s hardly the norm for the system.
articles.abstract: A substantial modification of their mortgage helped Amy and Robert Ahleman keep their home. But while their story is uplifting, it’s hardly the norm for the system.
articles.lead_paragraph: TWO and a half years ago, Robert and Amy Ahleman, a construction contractor and a financial services employee, were mired in a mortgage nightmare. After missing just one loan payment on their modest, well-kept bungalow in Bensalem, Pa., the couple began receiving notices from their lender. Default fees and eviction threats followed.

articles.headline: How Superstars’ Pay Stifles Everyone Else
articles.snippet: The “superstar effect” drives up pay for athletes, entertainers and Wall Street executives, concentrating wealth with only a few Americans and limiting others’ chances of moving up.
articles.abstract: The “superstar effect” drives up pay for athletes, entertainers and Wall Street executives, concentrating wealth with only a few Americans and limiting others’ chances of moving up.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was adapted from “The Price of Everything: Solving the Mystery of Why We Pay What We Do,” by Eduardo Porter, an editorial writer for The New York Times. The book, to be published on Jan. 4 by Portfolio, examines how pricing affects all of our choices.

articles.headline: Fears Growing of Mugabe’s Iron Grip Over Zimbabwe
articles.snippet: Warning signs are proliferating that President Robert Mugabe is planning to seize untrammeled control during the elections he wants next year.
articles.abstract: Warning signs are proliferating that President Robert Mugabe is planning to seize untrammeled control during the elections he wants next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe  The warning signs are proliferating. Journalists have been harassed and jailed. Threats of violence are swirling in the countryside. The president’s supposed partner in the government has been virulently attacked in the state-controlled media as a quisling for the West. And the president himself has likened his party to a fast-moving train that will crush anything in its way.

articles.headline: Deepwater Horizon’s Final Hours
articles.snippet: Interviews, sworn testimony and statements from crew members show that the oil rig should have weathered the well blowout, but it didn’t because every one of its defenses failed.
articles.abstract: Interviews, sworn testimony and statements from crew members show that the oil rig should have weathered the well blowout, but it didn’t because every one of its defenses failed.
articles.lead_paragraph: The worst of the explosions gutted the Deepwater Horizon stem to stern.
articles.byline: By David Barstow, David Rohde and Stephanie Saul

articles.headline: Cables Portray Expanded Reach of Drug Agency
articles.snippet: Diplomatic cables show American drug agents balancing diplomacy and law enforcement in places where politicians can be as devious as traffickers.
articles.abstract: Diplomatic cables show American drug agents balancing diplomacy and law enforcement in places where politicians can be as devious as traffickers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Drug Enforcement Administration has been transformed into a global intelligence organization with a reach that extends far beyond narcotics, and an eavesdropping operation so expansive it has to fend off foreign politicians who want to use it against their political enemies, according to secret diplomatic cables.
articles.byline: By Ginger Thompson and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Obama Returns to End-of-Life Plan That Caused Stir
articles.snippet: Advance care planning, which touched off a political storm over “death panels,” will be covered under Medicare — a “quiet victory” for supporters.
articles.abstract: Advance care planning, which touched off a political storm over “death panels,” will be covered under Medicare — a “quiet victory” for supporters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When a proposal to encourage end-of-life planning touched off a political storm over “death panels,” Democrats dropped it from legislation to overhaul the health care system. But the Obama administration will achieve the same goal by regulation, starting Jan. 1.

articles.headline: Visitors See North Korea Still Stunted by Its Isolation
articles.snippet: A carefully monitored visit to North Korea offered hints of why its leaders might be eager to resume international aid and trade.
articles.abstract: A carefully monitored visit to North Korea offered hints of why its leaders might be eager to resume international aid and trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: PYONGYANG, North Korea  Girls’ soccer teams waged a fierce battle outside a huge gymnasium. Two young brides, one resplendent in a white gown and the other in deep pink, married sweethearts in a snowy square. Parents pulled toddlers on plastic sleds. Pedestrians lined up at kiosks to buy baked sweet potatoes and pancakes.

articles.headline: Gadgets Bring New Opportunities for Hackers
articles.snippet: As Web-ready devices proliferate, consumers may run into new scams that play off the products’ features.
articles.abstract: As Web-ready devices proliferate, consumers may run into new scams that play off the products’ features.
articles.lead_paragraph: Researchers at Mocana, a security technology company in San Francisco, recently discovered they could hack into a best-selling Internet-ready HDTV model with unsettling ease.

articles.headline: Taliban Fighters Appear Blunted in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The Haqqani network has not conducted a complex, large-scale attack in Kabul for seven months.
articles.abstract: The Haqqani network has not conducted a complex, large-scale attack in Kabul for seven months.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The deadliest group of Taliban fighters in Afghanistan has not conducted a complex large-scale attack in the capital city of Kabul for seven months, its momentum stymied as elite American-led commandos have escalated raids against the militants’ bomb makers and logisticians.

articles.headline: New Voters May Sway Fed Actions
articles.snippet: As the Federal Reserve debates its $600 billion effort to nurse the economic recovery in 2011, four men will have a newly prominent role in influencing the central bank’s path.
articles.abstract: As the Federal Reserve debates its $600 billion effort to nurse the economic recovery in 2011, four men will have a newly prominent role in influencing the central bank’s path.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As the Federal Reserve debates whether to scale back, continue or expand its $600 billion effort to nurse the economic recovery, four men will have a newly prominent role in influencing the central bank’s path.

articles.headline: Online Bazaar Builds on Its Base With Sense of Community
articles.snippet: Started as a way for hobbyists and crafty types to sell their goods, Etsy has blossomed into a thriving e-commerce site.
articles.abstract: Started as a way for hobbyists and crafty types to sell their goods, Etsy has blossomed into a thriving e-commerce site.
articles.lead_paragraph: In technology circles, people talk about the merits of eating your own dog food  making sure your company is actually using the same products or services it is selling.

articles.headline: Hollywood Moves Away From Middlebrow
articles.snippet: Moviegoers have sent a message that seems obvious but has often been forgotten: make a good product, or we won’t buy.
articles.abstract: Moviegoers have sent a message that seems obvious but has often been forgotten: make a good product, or we won’t buy.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When negative Twitter commentary seemingly torpedoed the Sacha Baron Cohen film “Brüno” in July 2009, movie executives started talking in solemn tones about the ability of social networking to sway attendance. The era of using marketing to trick consumers into seeing bad movies was drawing to a close.

articles.headline: In ‘Daily Show’ Role on 9/11 Bill, Echoes of Murrow
articles.snippet: Jon Stewart’s role in pushing for a bill to provide health care for 9/11 responders has drawn comparisons to Edward R. Murrow.
articles.abstract: Jon Stewart’s role in pushing for a bill to provide health care for 9/11 responders has drawn comparisons to Edward R. Murrow.
articles.lead_paragraph: Did the bill pledging federal funds for the health care of 9/11 responders become law in the waning hours of the 111th Congress only because a comedian took it up as a personal cause?
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Brian Stelter
